Award.AwardTitle: Assessing the Learning Gains of Manufacturing Students in an Integrated Hands-on Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The lack of hands-on experience is one of the major competency gaps in engineering education. This project lead by Wayne State University is addressing this problem through continued work on the Manufacturing Integrated Learning Lab (MILL). The MILL model for engineering education uses team based projects, coordinated across multiple courses, culminating in the design and making of a functional product. The unifying theme is the design and fabrication of a functional product that students encounter repeatedly from different perspectives in several different courses. The MILL curricula has shown excellent learning gains at the sites where it has been implemented. In this project the hands-on MILL model will be expanded to additional institutions including Macomb Community College, Henry Ford Community Colleges and Prarie View A&M, one of the Historically Black College and Universities (HBCUs). The assessment methods developed to measure student learning gains in the MILL program will be tested in this expanded implementation. Results regarding the learning gains for students in MILL-type curricula, along with a unique standardized assessment incorporating a realistic physical manipulative, will prepare the MILL Model for a national scale-up. This project will demonstrate a flexible, effective, low cost and readily transferrable manufacturing engineering curriculum model that prepares a diverse and skilled workforce that meets industry needs.

This project will use psychometrically validated standardized testing to evaluate and validate attainment of target hands-on competencies. This is an innovative use of standardized testing for programmatic evaluation. This approach can document attainment of specific targeted learning outcomes. By comparing performance on the test instrument between intervention groups and comparison non-intervention groups, the project will document the learning gains attributable to the MILL Model intervention. The project will deploy this instrument at the four MILL implementation sites as well as three additional comparison sites. A repeated measures MANCOVA will be conducted to assess the magnitude of the effectiveness of the MILL Model in increasing student learning outcomes in engineering competencies. Analysis of the comparative performance of the two groups will be undertaken to ascertain the learning gains attributable to implementation of the hands-on MILL Model curriculum. The pool of available psychometrically validated assessment items will also be expanded during the course of the project. This effort to assess the learning gains of a large and diverse set of manufacturing engineering students in an integrated hands-on curriculum will yield information critical to meeting industrial needs for appropriate skilled manufacturing engineers. The use of a validated standardized test incorporating a physical manipulative to evaluate attainment of hands-on engineering abilities will also help to inform the development of assessment tools for hands-on activities throughout the STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was motivated by industry’s identification of the lack of hands-on experience as one of the major competency gaps in engineering education. In recent years, many new teaching pedagogies incorporating hands-on experiences have been developed in response to this need. This research focused on whether it is possible to document any differences in student learning outcomes that are directly attributable to such new pedagogies.

The research design was to use a psychometrically validated standardized test to assess student performance at two sets of institutions. One set was made up of four institutions that had implemented an experiential learning intervention called the MILL Model. The second set was composed of three comparable institutions that used traditional teaching techniques. To assess learning gains, the same test was administered at all institutions at the beginning of the academic year and at then again at the end of the year. Within each set of institutions, the performance difference between the two test administrations would represent the learning gains achieved over the course of the year. Across the two sets of institutions, differences in learning gains (if any) would show the relative effectiveness of the MILL Model intervention in boosting student performance. In a feature targeted at the experiential learning, the standardized test instruments used incorporated a physical manipulative to evaluate attainment of particular hands-on skills.

The seven institutions participating in the project ranged from research intensive, to Historically Black, and Hispanic Serving institutions; as well as two Community Colleges. Thus, the project inherently served a diverse population including underrepresented groups, many of whom are first generation to college.

The first year of the project was used to refine a standardized test that had been developed under previous funding. Tests were administered to students at all participating institutions and the results were used to analyze the test questions themselves to ensure content validity and test reliability. As a result of this early analysis, the pool of questions incorporated into the test was expanded, a number of test questions were revised and some were removed entirely and replaced by other questions. The tests were subjected to extensive psychometric analysis to establish their validity and reliability. The results of the analysis indicated excellent structure of the test instruments. The average difficulty index P of the test is close to the middle point of 0.5 which is considered ideal for standardized tests. This demonstrates that standardized tests can be used to authenticate student attainment of target hands-on competencies. The use of standardized tests can conveniently document attainment of specific targeted learning outcomes for accreditation and other assessment purposes. The accompanying psychometrically validated standardized tests can be used as instruments for outcomes assessment to help document attainment of targeted learning outcomes for program assessment, accreditation, and other assessment purposes.

In the second year of the project, the revised test instrument was administered to students as a pre-test and posttest at the two sets of institutions. On analyzing the test results, the test of the difference in performance between the MILL implementing schools and the comparison schools was found not to be statistically significant. Therefore, it was not possible to establish definitively whether the implementation of the MILL Model led to any improvement in student performance on the assessment instrument.
